Dispute_Type: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) compliance
Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer's decision to deny permanent residency based on excessive demand for health services is reasonable
Evidence_Assessment: Conflicting medical evidence regarding Rebif treatment costs and coverage; Health Canada's opinion versus private funding offer
Decision_Outcome: Visa denial based on potential excessive demand on health services
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate that health condition will not cause excessive demand
Credibility_Factor: Visa officer did not assess credibility of Mr. Jafarian's offer to pay or Quebec's potential coverage
Legal_Rule: A person is inadmissible if their health condition may reasonably be expected to cause excessive demand on health services, defined as exceeding $5,000 annually in government-funded costs
Procedural_Issue: Lack of independent analysis and failure to consider all relevant evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged procedural unfairness and unreasonable interpretation of excessive demand
Outcome_on_Merits: Decision found unreasonable due to lack of procedural fairness
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Violation of procedural fairness: officer relied solely on Health Canada without considering conflicting evidence
Key_Evidence_Considered: Annual cost of Rebif ($15,000), source of funding (private vs public), Mr. Jafarian’s financial undertaking
Legal_Framework: IRPA, Canadian immigration law, administrative law principles
Applicant_Challenge: Challenging the reasonableness and fairness of the visa officer’s decision
Defendant_Response: Relied on Health Canada’s assessment without further inquiry
Evidence_Type: Medical reports, financial undertakings, government opinion
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the visa officer’s decision
Outcome: Visa denial set aside; case remanded
Legal_Provision: Section of IRPA relating to excessive demand on health services
Authority: Health Canada, Visa Officer, Federal Court
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Excessive demand on health services due to multiple sclerosis treatment costs
Applicable_Process: Permanent residency application under economic class with health admissibility screening
Outcome_of_Review: Decision quashed, matter remitted for redetermination
Governing_Rule: Excessive demand threshold of $5,000 per year in publicly funded health services
